discussion.p: Daniel writes in a private email:

blockquote.p: - 3.1 'Decimal type encodings' says in its note:
blockquote.pre: "this implies that sizeof(std::decimal::decimal32) == 4, sizeof(std::decimal::decimal64) == 8, and sizeof(std::decimal::decimal128) == 16."
blockquote.p: This is a wrong assertion, because the definition of 'byte' in 1.7 'The C+ + memory model' of ISO 14882 (2nd edition) does not specify that a byte must be necessarily 8 bits large, which would be necessary to compare with the specified bit sizes of the types decimal32, decimal64, and decimal128.
The three decimal encoding formats defined in IEEE-754R correspond to the three decimal floating types as follows:

ul.li: decimal32 is a decimal32 number, which is encoded in four consecutive bytes octets (32 bits)
decimal64 is a decimal64 number, which is encoded in eight consecutive bytes octets (64 bits)
decimal128 is a decimal128 number, which is encoded in 16 consecutive bytes octets (128 bits)

p.del: [Note: this implies that sizeof(std::decimal::decimal32) == 4, sizeof(std::decimal::decimal64) == 8, and sizeof(std::decimal::decimal128) == 16. --end note]
